qas.question: When did the first aeroplane reach Bermuda?
Why did the plane have to land twice before reaching Bermuda?

answers.text: once because of darkness and again to refuel

qas.question: What improved thanks to the Royal Air Force in 1933?
Who began experimenting with flights from Berlin to New York, stopping in the azores?
What is Detroiter Stinson a type of?
What improved in 1936 because of the Royal Air Force?
Who began to experiment with seaplane flights in 1933?

context: After several failed attempts, in <a0_0>1930<a0_0/> the <b4_0>first aeroplane<b4_0/> reached Bermuda. A Stinson Detroiter <b5_0>seaplane<b5_0/> flying from New York, it had to land twice in the ocean: <a1_0>once because of darkness and again to refuel<a1_0/>. <a2_0><b6_0>Navigation and weather forecasting<b6_0/><a2_0/> improved in 1933 when the Royal Air Force (then responsible for providing equipment and personnel for the Royal Navy's Fleet Air Arm) established a station at the Royal Naval Dockyard to repair (and supply replacement) float planes for the fleet. In 1936 <a3_0><b7_0>Luft Hansa<b7_0/><a3_0/> began to experiment with seaplane flights from Berlin via the Azores with continuation to New York City.
